talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Bolkus for the question. I have seen press reports that there were 2,000 cases pending. But the government does not believe that cash compensation is an appropriate response to this issue. The government also does not support setting up any sort of tribunal to issue cash payments. It is the government's view that people wanting cash compensation should pursue their legal claims through the courts. The federal government is not alone in this view. No state or territory government has set up a compensation scheme. Following the outcome in the recent New South Wales case, Premier Bob Carr said he did not support cash payments to compensate for past injustices. He said:

answer.para: We have got to move beyond the idea that we can do it by making a cash payment to compensate for things that happened in our past.
I note that Senator Ridgeway commented on the issue last week. He said:
. . . the question of reparation for suffering is something that needs to be dealt with by the courts.

Even the Queensland government does not support cash compensation. Last week, on 27 August, in settling a claim with a former separated child, the government did not pay monetary compensation as part of that settlement. Cash payments are impractical and do not solve the problems associated with forced separation. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report itself said:
. . . assisting family reunions is the most significant and urgent need of separated families.

That is why family reunion is the cornerstone of the government's $63 million response to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report. It includes the Family Reunion Program administered through ATSIC, and separate funding for access to records, personal and family counselling, oral history recording and culture and language maintenance. Furthermore, the government is providing a record $2.2 billion annually in indigenous specific programs and assisting indigenous Australians to overcome the historical and continuing disadvantages they face.

This annual funding, which goes towards 390,000 indigenous Australians, includes the government's priority areas of $222.5 million on health, $365 million on housing and infrastructure, $957.3 million on education and employment and $60.4 million for economic development. As well, $216 million goes to native title and land rights, $60.5 million on law and justice and $45.3 million for cultural protection. On top of this, another $48 million is available every year forever from the $1.3 billion land fund set up to help indigenous people buy land. The government is commit ted to assisting indigenous Australians overcome the disadvantage they face today as a result of past injustices.

There are cases before the Federal Court in the Northern Territory and it is therefore inappropriate to make any comment in relation to them. It was not the government which instigated these proceedings, but the plaintiffs. The government is only acting on behalf of taxpayers in defending this case. It is not just this government that has defended this sort of litigation. The previous federal government defended the original litigation in the case of Kruger and Bray, which was based on constitutional issues. The New South Wales government also recently successfully defended similar litigation.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question, and I suggest the minister actually try answering the question rather than referring solely to cash payments. The solution may very well be in all those other mechanisms you mention, Minister. In light of this week's resolution from the government's independent advisory council, the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, will the Howard government now reconsider its opposition to last week's Labor amendments to the parliamentary resolution which called:

question.para: . . . for the establishment of appropriate processes to provide justice and restitution to members of the stolen generation through consultation, conciliation and negotiation rather than requiring indigenous Australians to engage in adversarial litigation . . .

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The government has already responded to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report in providing $63 million. As I said previously, the primary recommendation of that report said:

answer.para: That we should assist family reunions is the most significant and urgent need of separated families.
And that is what we are doing.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill. I refer to the collapsing orange roughy fishery and in particular to incidents on the South Tasman Rise. Is it the case that, despite five warnings and extensive diplomatic pressure, New Zealand and South Africa continued to raid and repeatedly plunder straddling stocks of orange roughy? How will the government ensure other countries work within an agreed and sustainable national management framework as international law requires? Next time this is brought to the government's attention, will the minister send Australian enforcement to demonstrate how serious the government is about unreported, unregulated and illegal fish catch movement?

—I am surprised by aspects of the question, because Australia and New Zealand have both agreed to ban fishing on the South Tasman Rise until a new regional agreement has been negotiated. In relation to other countries, certainly there was a recent incident when three South African vessels and one vessel registered in Belize were discovered fishing a spawning aggregation of orange roughy in an area of the STR which was very close to the Australian fishing zone. As a result of the discovery and diplomatic actions by Australia, the governments of both South Africa and Belize cooperated in bringing the fishing to a halt. Some may argue that that is an almost unprecedented level of cooperation in this area. The South African government advised Australia that it had revoked the licences of its vessels, while Belize deregistered its vessel. I would have thought that the prompt action of South Africa and Belize in relation to the matter should have been applauded. It was certainly deserving of being applauded, and that sort of international cooperation by states is something that the Australian government would want to encourage.

answer.para: We do say that all countries must recognise their obligations under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and the United Nations fish stocks agreement covering highly migratory and straddling fish stocks in particular, and that it is the responsibility of governments to ensure their flag state vessels use appropriate fishing practices and manage the fish stocks responsibly. That is the approach of the Australian government, and when instances occur, as has been referred to, on the high seas it is good to see that diplomatic action can result in responsible states taking action against fishing vessels fishing in an inappropriate way.

The issue of orange roughy is important. Historically in Australia it has not always been a happy story. I reflect upon the fact that, in 1990, fishing efforts reached a high of 53,000 tonnes whereas the current TAC is something just over 5,000 tonnes. That is a demonstration in itself of the extent to which Australian vessels at that time over-fished the resource within Australian waters. Australia was warned and has now acted, and we would urge other states to join with us cooperatively to ensure that fishing on the high seas is also conducted in a responsible way.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, without conclusive stock assessment, how can the government set quota for 150-year-old fish? Why doesn't the government close down the orange roughy fishery until it has defensible scientific evidence that it is sustainable?

—Perhaps I did not make it clear: in relation to fishing on the high seas in the vicinity of Australia—and I use the example of the South Tasman Rise—Australia and New Zealand both agreed on a voluntary basis to ban fishing until the stocks have been adequately assessed and new regional arrangements consistent with the sustainable fishing of those stocks are put in place. In relation to fishing within Australian waters, those stock assessments have been taken and, as a result of those stock assessments, the TACs have been very substantially reduced. That is the very point I was making.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Incomplete Commercial Property

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Minister, on the commencement of the GST next year, how will taxpayers determine the capital value of an incomplete commercial property as at 30 June 2000? Will that valuation include just cost to date, or could it also include cost to date plus the discounted value of future rental returns in that valuation?

—Thank you for the question. With a property that is not completed you have the right to value the property on 30 June and the GST applies to the completion materials used after that particular date. That is the general principle. On the other matters that you raise, Senator, I will check with the Australian Taxation Office and provide you with an answer.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. While the minister is checking that issue, could he also take on notice this question: in regard to an incomplete commercial property development as at 30 June next year—which is proposed to be sold upon completion—how will the profit attribution factor be calculated on the pre- and post-GST profit components?
—I will check with the Australian Taxation Office, Senator.
—I call Senator Brown.

—Can I proceed on a point of order first, Madam President? You will have noticed that the One Nation senator also stood because there is confusion as to who gets this question after Thursday's reallocation of a question to the Democrats. Could you help the chamber by furnishing any documents you have to show the arrangement between the government and the Democrats in reallocating extra questions to the Democrats?

—There is no point of order. It is a matter for the parties to organise any agreement on questions and I suggest you take it up with the appropriate whips. But you may ask your question now I have called you.

—On another point of order, Madam President, you made a ruling based on what you said was an agreement which can have involved only the Democrats and the coalition. I wonder whether you would cite that agreement, because you have made that ruling and you gave them the question on Thursday.

—I did not make a ruling on a point of order on Thursday, because there is no order of the Senate which relates to the order in which questions are asked. I thought I had made that plain on Thursday. There is no point of order in relation to this matter. It is a matter to be taken up outside the chamber amongst the parties involved, including you.
—You made the ruling on Thursday—
—I did not make a ruling, Senator.
—You gave the question to the Democrats.
—I can only make a ruling on an order of the Senate. You may ask a question if you wish.
—Yes, I will proceed with that. We will get somewhere there.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, following the SBS TV Dateline program last week and a report by Anthony Balmain in both the Sydney Morning Herald and the Age which says, amongst other things, that the Australian government colluded with Indonesian and other governments to fraudulently deny the people of West Papua an act of choice on the basis of one person, one vote. The government at that time, in 1969, held a number of documents which showed the process to be fraudulent. Will the government undertake an independent inquiry into these extraordinarily important and damning documents? If it will not do an independent one, will it support a parliamentary inquiry to the same end and a review of the United Nations decision to accept that fraudulent process of imposing military rule on West Papua?

—The 1969 act of free choice was accepted by the United Nations. Australia and all other members of the UN in 1969 accepted the result and Australia recognises Irian Jaya as part of Indonesia. In our view, it is not for the present government to comment on or explain the policies of the then Australian government, the United Nations and the international community in relation to Irian Jaya, which were made in the context of international support for completing the process of Indonesia's decolonisation from Dutch rule. Of course we strongly encourage Indonesia to ensure that international human rights standards are maintained in Irian Jaya and that grievances are redressed through dialogue and consultation.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The question is whether the minister is acquainted with a UN document, available to the Australian government before the 1969 so-called act of free choice which was nothing of the sort, which commented that personal political views of the UN team were that 95 per cent of the Irianese, that is the West Papuans, supported the independence movement and that the act of free choice was a mockery. I ask: how can this government live with an act that was a mockery, that is now known to be a mockery and which keeps civil rights and freedoms denied to two million people, our close neighbours to the north of this country?

—I know of the public suggestions and the references to which Senator Brown is referring. However, it remains the position of our government anyway that it is not appropriate for us to seek to explain the decisions of a government some 30 years ago. The important issue now is how to go forward, and the Australian government takes the view that Irian Jaya is part of Indonesia and that we should work with Indonesia to do our best to ensure the maintenance of high human rights standards and the sorts of values that we believe to be important. To seek to reconstruct the past we do not think could serve any positive or useful purpose for the people of Irian Jaya or anybody else.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Insurance Premiums

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Is the minister aware that HIH Insurance, one of the largest insurers in the country, has just booked a $50 million abnormal expense due to the GST? Is the government also aware of comments by the chief executive of HIH, Mr Williams, who stated:

question.para: We're saying that's a cost that we've got to bear and it's unfair that our shareholders should have to wear it. We're hoping that at the end of the day the Government will do what they did in New Zealand and that is introduce a transitional process that allows it to be recouped.

Will the government be taking Mr Williams's advice and introducing a transitional process, as they did in New Zealand? If not, will it be appropriate for HIH and other insurers to recover the cost of the Howard-Lees GST through higher insurance premiums on such items as home insurance and car insurance?

talk.start.para: —Of course the insurance sector of the economy, along with other sectors of the economy, we believe, will ultimately benefit from the introduction of the GST. There are transitional issues which have been raised and there has been a widespread debate on that, but the fact of the matter is that in quite a number of areas we would expect insurance premiums to fall. For example, car prices will fall and therefore the repair of cars will also be cheaper.
—You've misled the public on this for months.
—We are seeing quite a number of areas where Labor has wholesale sales tax on a range of goods of 32 per cent, and in many of those areas the prices of those goods will fall.
—Premiums are up.
—Order! There are people interjecting who know they should not be.
—Thank you, Madam President. Prices will fall in relation to a range of goods, such as videos and TVs.

answer.para: Senator Sherry interjecting—

talk.start.para: —What about insurance?
—Senator Conroy and Senator Sherry, come to order.

—Household insurance involves the cover of those sorts of products, and of course the prices of those products have fallen. We think it is just not correct to assume that insurance premiums in every area will have to rise. I am arguing that, because of the cuts in Labor's wholesale sales taxes, a range of goods will in fact fall in price.
—Why is the ACCC letting them put premiums up? What about the ACCC?
—Order! Senator Conroy, I ask you to cease interjecting and to take note of the standing orders.

—Thank you, Madam President. So, as I said, I do not think the statement by Senator Crowley, in making broad assumptions about what will happen in insurance, is correct at all. Any claims that companies make will have to be justified to the tax office; they will have to be made according to law. We believe—and the government is on record as saying this—that the taxation system we are bringing in will be of great benefit to the Australian economy, of great benefit to business and of great benefit to individuals. I am sorry that Labor constantly opposes this. It seems to constantly oppose the major tax reforms that this government is bringing in.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like to remind the minister that what I said had nothing to do with the Labor Party and everything to do with what the health insurance industry spokesperson was saying. So, before you race off on another tangent, Minister, could you have another shot given, as you have just said, that the ANTS documents predict cost savings to the insurance industry of $40 million and to the finance investment and insurance industry of $710 million? How is it that the HIH have had to provide for a $50 million abnormal expense due to the GST? Who is correct on this issue, Minister—the government or the insurers?

—Senator, I have not seen how that figure is calculated by the health insurance people and I think probably your question should, in the first place, be directed to them. The government's package, let me say, has been through a very rigorous process—an election, a massive Senate inquiry and a major Senate debate. The fact of the matter is that we believe that this tax reform is of great benefit to the Australian economy, of great benefit to business and of great benefit to individuals. If you like, Senator, I will—out of courtesy to you—have a closer look at what this particular insurance body are saying. But anyone who makes claims has to make those claims according to law and they have to be justified to the tax office.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, Senator Alston. Will the minister inform the Senate of what the government is doing to further assist small business? How will the government's new tax plan reduce compliance costs and help small business get on with business? Is the minister aware of any alternative policy proposals and is the government giving these any serious consideration?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —We are doing a great deal for small business because we understand that it is the engineroom of the economy. It is responsible for almost 50 per cent of jobs in the work force at the present time. In the decade to 1995 it was responsible for creating 1.1 million jobs, which is about 90 per cent of all the new jobs in that period. Our new tax system will actually make even better news for small business because it will dramatically reduce paperwork costs and it will very significantly simplify the whole taxation payment regime. Tax instalments will be based on actual sales in the quarter and provisional tax and the provisional tax uplift factor will be abolished, as will be a raft of other taxation arrangements and associated paperwork.

answer.para: Morgan Stockbroking recently gave a glowing report about the Australian economy and the benefits of the new tax system. It predicted that indirect tax reform would result in a 3.2 per cent increase in GDP. An increase of that magnitude would equate to 223,000 new jobs over four years. Those jobs of course will be overwhelmingly in the small business sector. Exporters' costs, on that scenario, would fall by some $4½ billion. The new tax system is simple for business because business will be able to claim a full credit for any GST paid on business purchases; we know that it relieves the burden on business by about $10 billion a year. The President of the New Zealand Employers Federation said recently that it only takes him about 20 minutes every two months to do his GST returns.

Why would anyone in their right mind be opposed to these reforms? Once again, Mr Beazley does not seem to understand policy realities. He has not yet of course disassociated himself from the secretary of the public transport union, who said recently, `How many small businesses pay a percentage of their profits to the ALP? How many small business people stood outside polling booths in the state election campaign for the ALP? It's our party, and if they don't want to be part of it they should leave.' There is a classic opportunity for Mr Beazley, who I see Glenn Milne says is in diabolical trouble, to actually come out and show that he is standing up for workers and not simply trade unions.

On the youth wages issue, he has been all over the shop. This is a critical issue for small businesses because, once again, they are the major employers of young people. But for seven years—according to Dr Blewett in his recently published and very disappointing memoirs—Mr Beazley championed a policy that he knew was not in the best interests of small business. In fact, according to Dr Blewett, Mr Beazley asked cabinet whether the ACTU realised—and I will have to paraphrase to sanitise this—how on the nose they were with the public on youth wages.

So how can you possibly aspire to the leadership of the nation if you remain the captive of the union movement to the extent that you say nothing on an issue when you know your policy position is wrong and when it is costing you out there in the wider electorate? All I can suggest, if the Labor Party wants to have one last chance, is that, when Senator Ray gets over there on that ultimate fact-finding mission and when he gets a bit sick of going to Carnegie Hall, the Met, the Frick and all those other wonderful places, he ought to look at how small business has transformed the economy in the United States and how it has led to significant productivity increases.
Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I know that you will probably prefer to be running around Central Park but just go a bit further and have a good look at how that economy works and see if you can apply any of the lessons back home here. It will be an absolute revelation.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Bank Compliance Costs

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Is the minister aware of concerns expressed by the Commonwealth Bank that all banks face `mind bogglingly' complex compliance issues as a result of the draft GST regulations for financial services? Is the minister also aware that the Commonwealth Bank has claimed that implementing the GST will cost the bank $35 million over two years and increase business costs by an extra $70 million to $100 million? Given that the CBA has said, `And we will be looking to recover that in some way', does this mean that banks will be free to ramp up bank fees and charges in order to pay for the costs of the Howard-Lees GST?

—I make a couple of points by way of introduction, Senator. This government has cut the cost of banking. This government's policies have ensured that people can now borrow at rates vastly below the rates which were available during the Labor years. For you to stand up in question time representing an opposition which in government saw home loan rates rising towards 17 per cent and heading north—when people can now get home loan rates in the order 6.5 per cent—and to suggest that this government is not worried about providing low cost finance to people is completely absurd. The Labor Party record is absolutely dreadful.

answer.para: What I think Senator Mackay was referring to—not draft regulations, Senator—is that we have released for consultation, with the banking sector, a document called The application of a goods and services tax to financial services. This has been provided to the banking sector for their consultation and feedback, so we are in the process now of getting that feedback from the banking sector. I would think that at this stage of the debate you will have people out there trying to make political points and to push the government in one direction or another. But there are two underlying points. One is that this government is providing the structure so that there are cheaper financial services to the Australian community than we have had in memory. This is in particular contrast to what happened under the terms of the Labor government. The second point—and I suspect that this report is what Senator Mackay was referring to—is that this document is now out to banks and other bodies in the financial services to get their feedback on the proposals the government has for the implementation of the GST.

talk.start.para: —Answer the question.
—That is the answer to your question, Senator.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, the question related to a quote from the Commonwealth Bank, which said, `And we will be looking to recover that in some way.' The Commonwealth Bank said that in relation to GST compliance. Given that the Howard government has claimed that the GST will save the banking and services sector a total of—I will remind you—$1.6 billion, how could the Commonwealth Bank have got it so wrong? Does this mean that the government will ensure that the ACCC will take action against any bank that jacks up fees and charges in order to pay for the cost of implementing and maintaining the GST?

There may be people like the CBA that have a different view, and they are entitled to put that view. It is very clear from the analysis we have done that this government is not only providing lower cost financial services to people through its reforms but that, with the removal of certain taxes like the FID, the wholesale sales tax and others, there will be very substantial savings. Anyone who attempts to claim expenses which cannot be justified may find it worth while to have a chat with the ACCC, because this government is determined to deliver the cost savings of this tax system to the Australian public. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator Minchin. I draw the minister's attention to the recently formulated oil code and I ask, first: is the minister aware of media reports that major oil companies were refusing to supply petrol stations if fuel was sold at a lower than recommended price, according to information gathered by a New South Wales government hotline? Is the minister also aware that in New South Wales callers to the petrol hotline claimed service station managers who lowered prices were subjected to threats and intimidation, and that they told of across-the-board increases on public holidays and pension days in certain areas and of bowser prices differing from the posted prices on the signboard? Does this mean that the oil code is not working?

—For the benefit of Senator Woodley, the oil code is a matter of some discussion between the parties and something we hope to finalise in the near future so that we can get agreement on the oil code in order that we can repeal the sites act and the franchise act. I am not sure what on earth Senator Woodley is talking about. The oil code is a government proposal which would be put into the Trade Practices Act and have the effect of being the mechanism by which the Trade Practices Act would protect small service station owners and ensure fair trade practices in the absence of the sites act and the franchise act. It is part of the government's proposals for reform of the petrol industry—an industry that the Industry Commission and the ACCC have agreed desperately needs reform. So I am not sure where Senator Woodley is coming from.

answer.para: What I do know is that the New South Wales Labor government's responsible minister has been utterly irresponsible in his attempts to play politics with the fact that the price of crude oil has doubled in the last six months, with consequences, naturally, for the prices of retail petrol. The New South Wales government minister has been roundly criticised by the service station industry itself for his cheap politicking on this issue, which has resulted in what I gather is now called `fuel rage' or something of that kind, because of the hysteria that he has created and the animosity he has single-handedly created towards the workers, the employees, at service stations. I would certainly take this opportunity to call on the New South Wales government, and in particular its fair trading minister, to behave much more responsibly on this very difficult issue in view of the fact that petrol station prices have obviously gone up because you cannot have a situation where crude oil prices double in six months and not have some consequences on petrol prices.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. Minister, I was aware of the whole debate, and particularly of the fact that the oil code and the legislation are yet to be debated in this place. I am saying to you that it seems that already there is a threat to the oil code because of the actions of major oil companies. Are you aware of a serious dispute, for instance, between the Motor Traders Association of Australia member Mr John Hinspeter and Caltex and the claim that this suggests that Caltex itself has no intention of observing the oil code? Do you believe the oil code will work to protect consumers and small petrol retailers?

—I am very confident that, if we can get agreement in relation to the oil code, it will work because it will be law. It will be part of the Trade Practices Act. It will be legally binding and will produce a much more sensible outcome and a much better petrol industry that will benefit consumers, the industry and service station proprietors. I think we all have to wake up to the difficulties in this industry. We do have the major oil companies suffering very low profitability and having difficulties with the refining industry. We have imports coming in from Singapore. We have a number of companies retailing petrol that are not subject to the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act or the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act. Inquiry after inquiry has agreed that there has to be reform of this industry and we look to the Senate to support that reform.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

debateinfo.title: SENATE: BROADCASTING OF PROCEEDINGS ON THE INTERNET

talk.start.para: —Order! I present a statement relating to a proposal to broadcast Senate proceedings on the Internet. The Manager of Government Business has indicated that he will give notice of a motion to authorise this proposal. I ask that honourable senators examine this statement before a motion is dealt with in the Senate.

—I have further information to add to the answer that I gave to a question from Senator Ludwig on 26 August 1999, in relation to legal fees. The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, and I seek leave to have it incorporated into Hansard .

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage (Senator Hill) to a question without notice asked today, relating to trade and the economy.
Let me begin by quoting from a speech on 30 May 1995. This was a speech in the House of Representatives. These words were said:

Yesterday the trade deficit was $2.25 billion. For the eight or ninth month in a row it was in excess of $2 billion. Australians are becoming desensitised to these outrageous figures. We are slipping further and further into the mire
and our chance is just thrown away.
In that same speech, the speaker concluded:
It is disgusting and it is outrageous that the people who are managing this company—Australia—can say that $2.25 billion in trade deficit is a good figure.

The speaker was actually referring to the current account deficit at the time, and the speaker is now the Minister for Trade, Mr Mark Vaile. It was a speech he made over four years ago. He was complaining of a monthly current account deficit of $2.25 billion then, or, on a quarterly figure, $7.75 billion. But today's quarterly current account deficit figure is $9 billion. That is $1¼ billion worse, and we have not heard from the minister, Mark Vaile, that this is disgusting and outrageous. For a government that promised to reduce the current account deficit, this surely is a disgusting and outrageous outcome.

One only has to look at the press release published by Mark Vaile to see why this government is trying to hide the facts from the Australian community. On 19 August, Mark Vaile published Exports of primary and manufactured products Australia 1998, an annual publication of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. He headed the accompanying press release `Manufactured exports grow in importance', as if manufacturing exports in Australia are doing better. On page 4 of this document, it reads:
Australia's exports of Manufactures grew 11 per cent per annum over the last decade, but fell 2 per cent to $24 billion in 1998.

What he is saying is that, during the period of the Labor government, exports of manufactured goods grew. So, if you take the 10-year span, the graph is still up. But if you look at the last two years, the graph goes down under this government. He is boasting about Labor's achievement, hiding his failure and the failure of this government on trade. Today's current account figures—an abysmal performance at $9 billion in deficit—demonstrate once again how this government has lost the plot in dealing with our external account.

Let me go one step further: let us look at what this government did when it was in opposition in running the debt truck around Australia and complaining about the level of foreign debt. In 1996 the level of foreign debt was $192 billion. Now, it is $242 billion—an increase of $50 billion or 26 per cent, or per capita, per Australian, a debt of $12,500. These are figures you do not hear from the Treasurer. It is inconvenient for him to talk about them. But it was this government, then in opposition, that complained about a foreign debt at levels much lower than is currently the case.

Let us look at the balance of trade in goods and services. In 1996 we had a surplus of $1.57 billion. In 1998-99 we have a deficit of $14.9 billion—a turnaround for the worse of $16 billion. This government has failed the Australian community. It has dishonoured its election pledges and it is driving this country into debt, sucking in imports, failing to produce offsetting exports and driving our current account deficit further and further into the red ink. This government stands condemned against its own performance indicators; it has failed to live up to what it promised. This country is facing a current account deficit crisis. This country is facing a foreign debt crisis. This country is facing a merchandise trade export crisis. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —What a lot of humbug we have heard from Senator Cook. We had a Labor government in power for 13 years. When the Asian economy was in boom and soaring ahead—when the tigers were roaring in Asia—we had high inflation, we had high unemployment, we had high interest rates, we had a high increase in overseas debt, and we had the recession we had to have.
—That was only three years ago.

—It was only three years ago. At a time when the tigers of Asia have been silenced in an economic downturn, we have unemployment going down, inflation at an all time low, and interest rates at an all time low. And they have the hide to stand up here and raise this issue! At least they have got off the other issue they were harping about last week and have got back to the main game. I think the message is getting across to them that they have been dealt out of the main game, and so today is a bit of an attempt to get back into the picture.

speech.para: The ALP are trying to justify their poor economic credentials. They are trying to attack the government's economic performance and trying to hide the dismal mess they left us to clean up. They left us, after 13 years, with unemployment at 11.2 per cent, and with a $10 billion deficit that was hidden by the Leader of the Opposition. It came out only after the election that they had hidden Beazley's black hole that he left us. The opposition spent totally beyond our means and left us with a decrepit, ramshackle wholesale sales tax system which could not provide for Australia's needs. That is what they left us. They were not game enough to bite the bullet, despite the fact they had a go at it in the 1980s. They decided that it was too hard and that they would just leave it.

Company confidence was at an all-time low, brought on by the Keating inspired recession that we had to have, which I referred to earlier. As Senator Kemp said today, interest rates were running at an all-time high of 17 per cent, making it almost impossible for average Australians to borrow for homes or for business start-ups. We saw small businesses hitting the wall because they could not afford to pay the interest on their loans.

We have turned the economy around in three short years. We have done something about the mess that was Labor's legacy to us and to Australians. We have taken strong action to reduce Labor's debt, to bring interest rates down, to remove the threat of inflation from wages and prices and to bring unemployment down. We now have a strong economy which has enjoyed eight consecutive quarters of economic growth. It is an economy which, unlike that under Labor, is enjoying high business confidence, with profits rising by 10.3 per cent. More than 40 per cent of Australians own shares, many for the first time. Unemployment is at its lowest in a decade at 7.2 per cent. There is no inflation in the economy and a successful debt reduction program has seen the budget in surplus, unlike Labor, which, when it was in government, continued to spend the money of those kids up in the gallery—the adults of the future—by borrowing against the next generation.

If you are going to talk about the current account deficit, let us get it in perspective. The appropriate measure of the current account deficit, for the purposes of comparison, is the share of GDP. Some commentators know that, in dollar terms, the June quarter 1999 current account deficit of $9.4 billion exceeds the previous highest quarterly figure on record of $8.3 billion in March 1999. In level terms, the next highest on record was in the March quarter 1995, when it reached $7.7 billion. We might just note that in 1995 Labor was in government.

However, such comparisons of nominal figures are misleading in a growing economy. In nominal terms, GDP is at a record level. In nominal terms, wages are at record levels. In nominal terms, household disposable incomes are at record levels. In nominal terms, household consumption is at a record level. In nominal terms, private sector wealth is at a record level. That is the good-news story. All you can focus on is one aspect of the economy. When you have a downturn in the economies which purchase from Australia and to which we export, then of course we are going to see problems with exports. But I tell you what! I would rather have faced the economic downturn in Asia under a Liberal government than under a Labor government, with its record of mismanaging the economy.

talk.start.para: —The balance of payments figures released today by the ABS show a damning picture of Australia's current account and international investment picture. All the signs are pointing in the wrong direction; they point south. The figures point out major economic problems on the horizon, and a brief recital of the figures demonstrates the problem. The trend balance on the current account has blown out from $8.3 billion for the March quarter to $9 billion. Seasonally adjusted, the current account has blown out from $8.2 billion to $9.3 billion. Seasonally adjusted, the current account deficit for the June quarter was up a huge 13 per cent. Incredibly, the net international investment position deteriorated further to a liability of $353 billion. From March 1996 to June 1999 the net international investment position has blown out from $274 billion to $353 billion, or an increase of 29 per cent in the life of this government alone. A large portion of this additional liability comes from debt. Since the coalition came to power, this liability has been increasing at an annual rate, compounded, of 10 per cent per annum.

speech.para: The government likes to claim credit for low and deteriorating levels of unemployment, low and steady inflation figures, higher levels of investment and sustained levels of GDP growth. It likes to claim credit for fireproofing the economy from the downturn in Asia. But if this credit is allocated to the current government, it cannot escape the statistics that suggest our growth and our rise in living standards are both illusory and temporary. This is because the growth is funded by borrowing, by an increase in overseas debt and by a binge in consumption. Simply put: Australians—both personal in the household sector and business in the corporate sector—are engaged in a consumption binge.

Debt is being raised to maintain current living standards. You see it in the high levels of up-market cars being imported, the higher levels of more expensive consumer durables being imported, the boom in property prices in better suburbs of mainland Australia, the huge rise in personal debt and the huge rise in credit availability and use all around Australia. The problem of a debt financed consumption binge lays squarely at the doors of the current government. This government is remiss in three fundamental areas: it has no savings policy to fund our consumption binge; it has no industry policy to overcome our growing current account deficit on goods; and, finally, it has no trade policy to gain access to new markets or to build upon areas of comparative advantage or strength in the Australian economy.

We can already see the growing signs of serious downturn in our own decline. Currency values are dropping. In recent months the Australian dollar has gone from 67 cents down to around 63 cents. The international marketplace is saying we are worth less—over the last three or four months requiring eight per cent more Australian dollars to service existing debt levels. The spread between Australian bonds and US bonds has gone out to over 50 points as at last Friday. This means that the price of borrowing or interest rates will have to increase. Sooner, not later, our interest rates will move to fund our consumption habits and to fund our increasing borrowing and increasing debt.

These problems are capable of being fixed by being serious about having a savings policy in this country. A clear start would be again to look at increasing the quantum of compulsory superannuation from nine per cent to 15 per cent. This is simply done by saving some of the budget surplus as opposed to wasting it on more debt financed consumption, as is the intention of the current government from 1 July next year. Already household saving has dropped from around 18 per cent 20 years ago to 12 per cent 10 years ago, so that now it just approaches zero, just like the US. Just as Japanese bond holders can sell, not buy, US bonds, they are doing that already with Australian issued bonds. They can sell them now and buy them for a lower price for a higher yield later. Savings levels in Australia need to increase dramatically. Next year there will be significant tax cuts. The general rate will drop to 30 per cent from higher levels. A portion of those tax cuts should be directed into national savings. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The current account deficit phenomenon goes back a long time. In fact, I can remember it being a very contentious issue in my university economics days. The issue we are looking at today was raised by Senator Cook. Senator Cook really failed to differentiate between those matters that the Australian government can control and external events.

speech.para: I think it is interesting that the Labor Party has suddenly acknowledged debt. When the Labor Party was in government from June 1983 to 1996, net foreign debt increased by 662 per cent from $25.2 billion to $191.9 billion. As a share of GDP—and this is the interesting and most relevant comparison—net foreign debt almost tripled from 14 per cent of GDP to 38 per cent. But if we look at today's statistics, we see that the June quarter current account deficit is 6.2 per cent of GDP. This figure is actually below many of the earlier peaks. The figure recorded for the March quarter of 1990 was 6.6 per cent of GDP—surprise, surprise, the ALP was in government—and 6.5 per cent of GDP was recorded in the March quarters of 1995 and 1986.

If we are looking at possible opposition criticism of the government, where is the substance? The substance, I maintain, is absolutely lacking. If we look at those issues that the Australian government has been able to control—and has controlled—we find that Australia has one of the lowest ratios of government debts to GDP of any country in the OECD.

Coming back to my earlier point, the very strong domestic demand of the Australian economy has fuelled a big rise in imports. Judging from the tenor of Senator Cook's remarks, he seems to be making a desperate plea to perhaps reintroduce massive tariffs to limit some of these imports or, alternatively, to reintroduce massive subsidies to exports, which would be contrary to GATT, Cairns and Uruguay type arrangements.

Where is the Labor Party coming from in terms of the message that it is attempting to send? Its messages are mixed, confused and out of date and not in keeping with what is happening globally. What Senator Cook fails to recognise is the resilience of the Australian economy, an economy which has managed to withstand the great crisis that has occurred in most countries to the north. Many of Australia's traditional markets actually got caught in that downturn. Labor senators were critical of Australia not opening up new markets. Perhaps the Labor Party has not been reading the overseas trade statistics in the last few years where we find that entirely new markets emerged and new products have come onto the export scene. New export markets are indeed a surprisingly good story.

What Senator Cook and Senator Bishop failed to say about interest rates is that interest rates are generally determined by what happens in the global economy. Australia is very much part of the global scene nowadays. Decisions by Dr Alan Greenspan in the United States influence interest rates in Australia. There will be an outflow of money from Australia, in this global economy, to those countries—particularly to the United States, when it offers higher interest rates. It is not surprising that, despite the resilience and the strength of the Australian economy, there will always be some money movements—called hot money—from one economy to another in response to interest rate movements. And that is exactly what we are experiencing at the present time. The surprising feature about interest rates in Australia is that they have not moved upwards more than they have. It is true that there has been a slight shift in certain fixed term rates.
If we look at Mr Mark Paterson's survey of investor confidence, he says that it is nothing short of extraordinary, with the level of business confidence rising by 7.1 per cent. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is a bit surprising to me that a number of Liberals have got up and, with straight faces, told us in no uncertain terms that the report issued today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics on the balance of payments positions is not anything to be worried about. You would think, from listening to Senator Watson, that people listening to our broadcasts out in the suburbs and in rural and regional Australia—

speech.para: Senator Patterson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Maybe we are not broadcasting. Senator Patterson will have to listen to me herself. You would think that we have nothing to worry about and that all is well and fine in this great land that we live in. If you move around this country like I do, particularly in my own state of New South Wales, you would know that there is not the sense of optimism and good tidings that you would think there is from hearing the speeches today from the coalition senators. I think people need to be reminded that the ABS report said that our trade is deteriorating, our current account deficit has blown out to a record level of more than six per cent of GDP, the deficit has increased by $1 billion in the June quarter, and we have had a 13 per cent blow-out in the total current account deficit for the quarter to a record $9.36 billion, seasonally adjusted.

speech.para: I can only talk on behalf of New South Wales, but once again those geniuses in the Liberal Party that run the New South Wales machine are running around the state with that debt truck. Do you remember the debt truck? It said, `We will reduce the debt once we get in.' But, according to these figures that have been published today, all we see is that we are going further and further into debt and we have no solutions to it.

One of the things that has not been commented on by the coalition is this: one of the worrying indicators is the decline in Australia's exports of elaborately transformed manufactures. These are the highly skilled manufacturing industries that were going up under the Labor government. Where are they now? They are declining, because this government will not invest in our future. It is all right for Senator Patterson to look up into the gallery and say to all the young people up there, `We are looking after your future.' You are not looking after their future at all. All you are doing is letting our economy and these manufactures slip further and further into the low-skilled, low wage industries. Under the Labor government, these elaborately transformed manufactures were increasing. They are declining, and I think that is one of the serious things to come out of this report, which has not been commented on by any of the speakers on the coalition side today.

When we think about these figures that have been released, we on our side see that there is a problem that needs to be addressed. The coalition has not been fair dinkum in presenting to the Australian people any solutions that will overcome this problem. All they have done is to give us a bash-up about 13 years in government. We did a lot of things to be proud of in 13 years in government, and if we get an opportunity we will do more of them.

I went to a conference in Wagga on the weekend with the National Party member for the Riverina, Kay Hull, and we heard some frightening statistics from people who live in rural and regional Australia. They have income levels that are nearly a third less than those of their metropolitan based fellow Australians. They pay more for things like fruit, vegetables, fuel, and for a lot of other things associated with living out in regional and rural Australia. They are not convinced that you are doing the right thing. They are convinced that you are letting their lifestyles and their standards of living decline. You have not come up with any solutions whatsoever, and I think you need to explain to people what you are going to do about the future.

talk.start.para: —Australia has one of the strongest economies in the developed world. It has high growth, high productivity, high jobs growth, low inflation, low interest rates, high GDP, record wages, high disposable income, household consumption at record levels, and private sector wealth at record levels. It is one of the strongest economies in the developed world, and this is Australia's greatest national achievement over the last decade. It is in fact Australia's great foundation stone for the future.

speech.para: Not long ago, everyone said that Australia was finished and that the Asian economic tigers would savage Australia. They did not; this country prevailed. Because of the economic management of the Howard government, Australia has done much, much better than anyone expected.
Senator Cook interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Half a dozen years ago, even Senator Cook would not have thought that Australia would be doing as well as it is today. This is perhaps Australia's strongest economic performance since man landed on the moon. While the government welcomes the opposition's concern, it is disconcerting that, with the opposition's record, they are seeking to rubbish Australia's great national achievement. Labor are claiming that we are living off a binge. Of course nothing could be further from the truth. This government has taken some very tough decisions. They were not always easy, but it has made them and they were the right decisions. It has taken the tough decisions today so that all Australians—including the young people who were in the gallery before—can live a little better tomorrow.

speech.para: This government is not a credit card government. It has a very proud record on the economy and, try as the opposition may, they really can do very little to dent it. Senator Patterson and Senator Watson put our case well and gave the background, as did Senator Kemp. Today's current account figure for the June quarter, which showed a deficit of about $9 billion, reflects the combined effect of a continued weakness in many of our export markets and at the same time the very great strength of our domestic economy. As Senator Watson pointed out, the June quarter result of about six per cent of GDP is actually below earlier peaks—the 6.6 per cent of GDP recorded under the Hawke government in the March quarter of 1990 and 6.5 per cent in the March quarters of 1995 and 1986. In the current financial year, the current account deficit is 5½ per cent, which is consistent with the budget forecast. As usual, quarterly outcomes have fluctuated around the year average estimate.

While the volume of exports has held up, the fall in export prices in the June quarter is a reminder of the difficult trading conditions for our exporters, particularly in East Asian markets, despite recent signs of a turnaround in some areas. The June quarter outcome has also been affected by the large falls in contract prices for bulk commodities which came into effect on 1 July 1999 largely in response to the slow-down in East Asia and particularly in response to the recession in Japan.

This government has a very proud record on the economy. Over the last few years this government's achievement has been second to none. In my lifetime there have been only a couple of years in the 1960s when the economy has been stronger. Interest rates now are what they were when I was born. We make no apologies for the superb performance of this government. The opposition harps on the current account deficit but, while it is perhaps troubling in some quarters, it will change, it will fluctuate. (Time expired)
