talk.start.para: —Much has been said in the last week or so about young people, given the arrangement reached on entrenching junior wage rates. Indeed, the coalition has done much to put into place a comprehensive range of measures to provide young people, including indigenous Australians, with increased access to education and training and increased opportunities to find employment. The coalition has successfully introduced the Work for the Dole scheme, based on the principle of mutual obligation. This scheme is conclusively showing that it can reunite unemployed young Australians with their communities and build the self-esteem of the young, unemployed participants.

speech.para: With the commitment of over $340 million over four years for its Work for the Dole program, the coalition has demonstrated that it really means what it says with this commitment. However, the government alone cannot solve youth unemployment. Community groups, individuals and the youths themselves have a fundamental role to play.

I am pleased to report to the Senate that such a community initiative to stem youth unemployment is occurring within Wyong Shire. While recently on a fact-finding mission visiting rural and regional communities in my home state of New South Wales, it was my pleasure to meet with members of Wyong Shire Council to discuss issues facing the youth of the Central Coast, in particular youth unemployment. My visit to the area was the culmination of a two-week visit to community and industry groups in a number of regional centres and the Central Coast. I was invited to the Central Coast by my colleague Jim Lloyd, the member for Robertson, and I was specifically invited to visit Wyong Council, in the neighbouring electorate of Dobell, by the Mayor of Wyong, Cliff Russell.

Of particular interest was an innovative youth project aimed at targeting youth unemployment and other youth issues. Whilst youth unemployment in the Wyong-Gosford region is below the national and state averages, it is still an unacceptably high 20 per cent. It is of concern that the Wyong region needs 2,000 new jobs a year just to meet the current demands of the population. Population growth in the region is 3.5 to four per cent. Currently, 33 per cent of the population have to commute to Sydney for employment and the area is crying out for an injection of industry that will bring local jobs. It certainly gives new meaning to the term `dormitory suburb'.

The Wyong Shire Council has seen youth unemployment as a problem for the region for an extended period, with youth rates, as I said, hovering around the 20 per cent mark. In May 1997, the council implemented a community plan that set forth the aspirations of the Wyong community to help the youth of the region find employment and directions for its implementation. One of the key objectives of the document was to provide young people with opportunities to put forward their own ideas and to generate their own solutions. After extensive community consultation, the council concluded that the youth of the Wyong district needed better facilities to accommodate their need in terms of youth specific health services, support services, and recreation and entertainment facilities.

In keeping with this objective, in December 1997 the council purchased a site at Hely Street, Wyong for a purpose-built youth facility. In April 1998 the Wyong council established a joint venture project with the Salvation Army to establish and operate the youth service on the Hely Street site. High unemployment, family breakdown and a lack of educational opportunities on the Central Coast led the Salvation Army to join the project which has become known as the Youth 2000 project.

The project will provide invaluable services for the region, including employment related courses to enhance numeracy, literacy, self-esteem and conflict resolution; facilities to job match youth with hopeful employers; chaplaincy and counselling; support for pregnant teenage girls and young mothers; and counselling for drug, alcohol and other addictions. The centre will also provide music and recording facilities, a skate park, basketball courts, a performing arts area and a youth cafe.

What is most unique about this project is the level of youth inclusion, from the initial design phase that included representatives from high schools across the shire to the appointment of six youth representatives to the permanent advisory board in charge of the project. Those involved have shown great commitment to the project, meeting out of school hours and rising to the challenge of responsibility that involvement with such a project entails. It was rewarding to see local youth playing such an active part in projects that will play a role in helping them to realise their potential.

What is also significant is that the development of the site has been partly constructed by Work for the Dole participants who work side by side with skilled labour hired by the Salvation Army. The coalition's Work for the Dole scheme aims to increase participants' work ethic and restore their links with the community, which certainly can help when seeking work. The Work for the Dole participants are not only gaining skills such as carpentry, concreting and bricklaying but are helping to contribute to facilities that will help them and other youth in the Wyong district in the future. The coalition's initiative in Work for the Dole allows community groups, local councils and other non-profit organisations to be involved in developing projects and running them. This is a fine example of the benefits of the Work for the Dole scheme, both for the participants and for the community in which they reside. Ruth Moncrieff, the managing director of the program, said:

After only one month, the participants were starting to regain their self-esteem and self worth. They are also making friends and learning new skills and have a reason to get out of bed two days a week.

What made this particular project stick in my mind is the positive way that the Wyong council and other groups and individuals in the community are attempting to address the problems in their regions. This is really assistance from the bottom up rather than the top down. In particular, I was impressed with how the council is seeking to redress what is an unacceptably high rate of youth unemployment in the Gosford-Wyong region, with all its attendant problems.

The project will give youth skills and self-esteem to bring about a lowering of youth unemployment rates in the region and, consequently, lower youth suicide rates—also a problem—and drug dependency within younger sections of the Central Coast community. The Youth 2000 project also has the potential to be a fantastic model for other similar projects across the country. Prior to completion, the project has already won an award at the International City/County Management Association awards in Washington. Wyong council won the award for the best program that enhances the quality of life for disadvantaged youth.

It was indeed a pleasure for me to see not only such an innovative project but one that has involved so many sections of the Wyong community. From local companies and com munity groups to schools and individuals, support across the community has been both significant and outstanding. Community response has been generous and heartfelt, with donations coming from the state government, BBC Hardware, Mitre 10, local registered clubs, the Wyong Rotary Club, local schools and, of course, the Wyong Shire Council. Of the $1 million needed to fund construction of the project, $750,000 has already been raised and donated through community support. Potentially this model youth project could be developed around the country to involve the community in youth programs. The centre encourages visitors and is an excellent example of what a committed community can do to work in tandem with government initiatives to provide long-term solutions. It gives young people not only job skills but a sense of purpose so that they really are fit for life.

talk.start.para: —In question time in the House of Representatives last Thursday and in the Senate last week a question was asked of the government about the future of the Australian dairy industry. In the House of Representatives, the shadow minister for agriculture, Gavan O'Connor, asked the minister, Mr Truss, what the government was doing to assist this multibillion dollar export industry to adjust to further deregulation, that deregulation being the end of the domestic market support arrangements and the removal of the remaining statutory controls on the price and supply of Victorian liquid milk.

speech.para: Mr O'Connor wanted to know why the government was taking so long to respond to a plan to help 13,500 farmers through what will clearly be a very difficult period of adjustment. The answer given by Mr Truss was most informative. However, if you are a dairy farmer, it was also very disturbing. Mr Truss said:
The dairy industry is responding to that decision.
He meant the decision by the Victorian government to deregulate the Victorian system completely. He also said:
The government will naturally deal with that package when it is put to us.

Those dairy farmers who have spent many months tramping around the corridors of this building putting their plan before this government generally, and Mr Truss and his office in particular, will be very disturbed to find that their efforts have been in vain.

At about the same time, Senator Alston in this place was on his feet dealing with the same matter. We obviously had Mr Truss not working off his brief and getting it wrong while Senator Alston, who eventually found his brief, was working off Mr Truss's brief and, in some respects, getting it right. While the minister was telling the other place that when the industry put forward a plan the government would look at it, Senator Alston in this place was saying:
The industry has put forward a plan.

We also had the minister calling on the Labor Party to make a constructive contribution. We then had Senator Alston reminding us that it was important to note there was a Senate inquiry currently under way into the dairy industry. He said:

It will report on 30 September, and there will be an opportunity not only to take account of the package put forward by the dairy industry but also to look at some of the other concerns that have been expressed.

Considering that the inquiry was initiated by the Labor Party, that sounds like a constructive contribution to me. In fact, the terms of reference for the inquiry were not only proposed by me on behalf of the Labor Party; they were endorsed by the office of the then minister, Mr Vaile. This matter was referred to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee because the former minister, Mr Anderson, and Mr Vaile had failed to do their job. They had failed the dairy industry.

The end of regulation in Victoria and the DNS on 1 July next year will have a dramatic impact on the industry and those regional economies throughout Australia that rely on it. The government has been aware of both these events and their impact for some considerable time. It is all very well for the minister, Mr Truss, to say that the industry has had fair warning. That criticism can be more easily directed at the government itself. The current national arrangements, along with the sunset clause, have been in place since 1992. The intention of the Victorian government about the future of regulation in that state has also been obvious.

The impact of further deregulation on the Australian dairy industry was also item 1A on the agenda of the meeting of Commonwealth and state agriculture ministers in Adelaide on 5 March. At that meeting, all ministers agreed that the time left to address the major issues was `critical'. Note that that was on 5 March. The ministers also noted advice from the Australian Dairy Industry Council on the matter. The ministers noted `the significant adjustment and commercial pressures which the industry needs to deal with'. Again, the ministers acknowledged that the time available to address major issues was critical.

The ministers also noted advice from Mr Vaile that as soon as a firm proposal was provided by the industry he would take it up with the federal government. Mr Vaile had that plan on his desk on 20 April this year. He and his office had detailed discussions with the Australian Dairy Industry Council well before then. On 5 March, the minister representing dairy farmers in the Howard government knew, firstly, that time was running out to find the most effective way to manage the radical change facing 13,500 farmers that make up an industry which generates $2 billion per year in export earnings. Secondly, he had advice from the industry on the impact of deregulation. Thirdly, he knew the significant adjustment and commercial pressures that had to be dealt with. Fourthly, he knew that the time available—that is, at 5 March—to deal with the significant adjustment and commercial pressures was critical. Fifthly, he gave a commitment to his fellow ministers that he would move quickly once the industry had presented a plan. The government has had that industry plan before it for 132 days.

Mr Truss and, before him, Mr Vaile have a whole department of experienced and competent officers at the end of a telephone. They could be in the minister's office within minutes. Both have had at their disposal the resources to undertake a proper process of consultation with Australian dairy farmers, but both have failed to activate those resources. Both have had at their disposal the resources to assess the plan presented by Mr Pat Rowley on behalf of the Australian Dairy Industry Council or look at other options, such as the one offered by the concerned dairy farmers group, but we have heard nothing.

Of course, the Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Party, Mr John Anderson, has at his disposal a department that has some considerable expertise in regional adjustment. But we have seen nothing from him either. Despite the best efforts of people like Pat Rowley and the representatives of the concerned farmers group, who have been genuine in their efforts to find a way through this policy dilemma, successive ministers have failed to give the matter the attention it deserves. It is the Senate committee, not the minister, that has provided a means by which the Australian Dairy Industry Council plan could be tested. We are scheduled to complete our hearings early next month. It has been the Senate committee, again, and not the minister, that has sought out alternative plans. It has been the same Senate committee, not the minister, that has sought to identify the regional impacts of further deregulation of the dairy industry.

This government has failed to take the initiative in finding a way through the consequences of the Kennett government's decision to deregulate its industry, and therefore, by default, deregulation in other states. Yet again the National Party has failed to take the initiative in the interests of people living in the bush. Yet again it has chosen, belatedly and reluctantly, to react to a problem. Yet again, as it did in a response to the growing problem of Ovine Johne's disease and just as it did in the crisis facing the wool industry, the National Party has failed.

Although Mr Truss is the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, the industry is really dependent on Mr Anderson, as the Deputy Prime Minister and the Leader of the National Party, to win cabinet room support for an acceptable package. That means that Mr Anderson must win the day against the cabinet dries, led by the Treasurer, Mr Costello. That will be the true test for Mr Anderson; it will determine whether he is fit to lead the National Party. We will see whether he really is a Pitt Street farmer or a champion of the bush.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Security Intelligence Organisation: Encryption Technologies

talk.start.para: —I rise this evening to discuss the issue of encryption technologies. I am conscious of the fact that, in this short amount of time, I could not possibly do justice to the breadth and depth of encryption technology, so instead I will concentrate on the issue of policy, in particular focusing on the 1996 review of policy relating to encryption technologies and the final report of that review, which is commonly known as the Walsh report.

speech.para: During 1996 the Secretary to the Attorney-General's department invited Gerard Walsh, a former Deputy Director of ASIO, to review the policy relating to encryption technologies and to offer a view as to whether legislative or other actions were indicated in the face of the information and communications revolution. In view of limited resources, the review did not invite written submissions or conduct public hearings but instead consulted with a representative sample of interested parties. A report was prepared by Gerard Walsh, dated 10 October 1996, and it was prepared and printed by the Australian Government Publishing Service. Deposit copies were sent to libraries and the report was listed for sale by the AGPS in January 1997, but the report was never made available for sale. It was withdrawn from the AGPS, and from their sales lists around the country, three weeks after its appearance there, apparently on the instructions of either the Attorney-General himself or the Attorney-General's Department.

There is no doubt that this report was written with the intention that it would be publicly available. Indeed, the foreword in the printed version of the report gave a mailing address and a fax number, as well as an email address, to which public comments could be forwarded. It is also noted that the closing date for public comments was to be 16 February 1997. These facts would seem to indicate that there was an intention to release the report publicly.

In March 1997 Mr Greg Taylor applied for a copy of the report under the Freedom of Information Act. Mr Taylor is a member of Electronic Frontiers Australia, a non-profit organisation which was formed to protect and promote the civil rights of Internet users. His initial request was refused on the basis that disclosure would cause damage to the security of the Commonwealth and prejudice law enforcement. Mr Taylor asked for a review of the decision, and he was sent a copy of the document, with about 40 deletions for the national security and law enforcement reasons I have already mentioned.

In January of this year another member of Electronic Frontiers Australia discovered a copy of the full uncensored report sitting in a library in Tasmania. The full report was subsequently released via the Internet. In February of this year a member of my staff borrowed an uncensored copy of the report from the deposit collection of the National Library of Australia. Also in February a letter was sent to a number of library deposit administrators by AusInfo, requesting the return of the copies of this report.

Why was the report withdrawn? Why are we discussing it now? There is no doubt that the report cuts very close to the bone, but probably with good reason. The availability and the use of encryption is intricately connected with communication privacy, transactional privacy and civil liberties generally. The report was intended to be a comprehensive review of the policies relating to encryption technologies, and it is indeed quite comprehensive. It includes a full range of recommendations, findings and conclusions which should be of vital importance to any discussion of information technology and law enforcement policy. Indeed, legislation was introduced earlier this year by the Attorney-General to implement some of the recommendations of the report. The legislation takes the form of a series of amendments to the ASIO enabling legislation. Of course, I will have a lot more to say about that at the second reading stage of that legislation, but I do want to draw attention to the fact that the expansion of ASIO powers should take place only after consultation on the recommendations of the Walsh report.

Encryption is a central requirement of communications and electronic commerce via networks such as the Internet. The communications and transactional privacy of users, and thus their confidence, is directly related to the availability of secure communication channels. Encryption is able to provide those secure communication channels, but the Australian government seems to have followed the United States along a path of highlighting the mythical dangers of readily available encryption rather than affirming the right of all Australians to private and secure communications and transactions.

As I said during the Internet censorship debate, any response to this type of speech is likely to include the standard refrains about the so-called `Four Horsepeople of the Infopocalypse'. These are paedophiles, organised criminals, drug traffickers and terrorists. With great respect to those people who list these standard enemies, the horses have bolted. We know that this group of miscreants have access to high-level encryption technology; indeed, one portion of the report which was removed from the version released under the FOI was a paragraph which stated:
Strong encryption, which cannot be defeated by law enforcement and national security agencies, is already available commercially or in the public domain.
With great respect to those people who made those deletions for the FOI request, this is not a secret, and certainly not a secret deserving of protection from release under the FOI provisions.

Interestingly, another excised paragraph of the report refers to a `range of encryption technologies, ranging from relatively unsophisticated through to DES'. This reference to DES as the pinnacle of available technology is now seriously outdated. Indeed, it was probably outdated at the time of writing. Earlier this year a DES-encrypted message was cracked by amateurs in less than 24 hours using brute force technologies. This would seem to indicate that DES is being broken far more rapidly by specialist agencies such as the Defence Signals Directorate, and yet DES encryption forms the basis of the security systems used by most banks and government agencies. In contrast, freely available encryption software, such as PGP—or pretty good privacy—provides orders of magnitude more security and has the advantage of using public-key techniques, which make the use of encryption in a communications environment significantly simpler.

Restrictions on the use of these technologies are simply not enforceable. An earlier policy suggestion—popular both in Australia and the United States—would have encouraged us all to use easily cracked encryption, with the obvious outcome that anybody using stronger encryption was doing so to cover up some illegal purpose. This, of course, is an outrageous suggestion. What is needed in any discussion of policy in this field is a realisation by governments that private communications are a right rather than a privilege. Currently there seems to be a view that the privilege of private communication should be extended only to law enforcement, surveillance and military agencies. Of course, that view is quite offensive. Australians deserve the highest level of protection for their personal and business communications, including the use of encryption where appropriate.

As mentioned earlier, encryption is also an essential component of electronic commerce systems. There is still a widespread lack of confidence among Internet users about the reliability and safety of electronic transactions. The low-level encryption available in Internet browsers exported from the United States provides a very flimsy guarantee of transactional security and privacy. Fortunately, Australians are world leaders in providing high-level encryption products for electronic commerce. In another bizarre twist of policy, it seems that these products cannot be exported from Australia even though they can be imported.

One of the other supposedly controversial paragraphs in the Walsh report questions the efficacy of export controls as a defensive strategy when no import controls exist. We know that products frequently evade the export controls of the United States or are available from unrestricted European sources. I would certainly not advocate the imposition of import controls but would instead argue for perhaps a more intelligent response. I am encouraged by some of the initiatives from the United States to legalise the sale and use of encryption. The proposals in the original Security and Freedom through Encryption—or SAFE—Bill seek to address the possibility of criminal use of encryption by making use in the furtherance of a criminal act an independent offence.

I call on the Attorney-General now to release the Walsh report in its entirety and to engage in a debate about the availability and use of encryption which would recognise the legitimate rights and liberties of Australians. Hopefully, we can do this without a single mention of the usual and probably illusory suspects.

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak tonight on the plight of former employees of the Selwyn Mine in Queensland, which is situated approximately 280 kilometres south of Mount Isa. Having spent many years negotiating agreements on behalf of the Selwyn employees and having had the opportunity on a number of occasions to visit the site and deal with a number of industrial relations matters, I feel very close to the problems that confront employees at present, particularly the grief that they are currently experiencing.

speech.para: Selwyn Mine, to put it in perspective, is a gold and copper mine owned by Arimco Mining that previously employed some 118 workers. On 26 March the Australian Workers Union was advised that all employees were terminated forthwith. At the date of the closure the workers were owed something in the order of $6 million in accumulated entitlements. Put bluntly, it averaged about $24,000 for each worker. Six months later, these workers have not received one cent of their entitlements. Many of the workers are struggling financially, trying to pay mortgages and supporting their families in the hope that they will soon receive their money. Unfortunately, a solution does not seem to be likely in the near future. It certainly has not materialised.

The mine received something in the order of $4.5 million from the sale of the final shipment of copper concentrate. That was realised in April and is known, as I understand it, as a floating asset. Rather than paying the money to the employees, the receiver and managers chose to use it to maintain the mine on a care and maintenance basis and to comply with various mine regulations. This was apparently done in the hope of receiving a larger sum upon the eventual sale of the mine.

The receivers have failed to respond to the AWU's request to pass this money on to the former employees, claiming that they are seeking legal advice—which was sought in about July and has still not materialised. It appears that the AWU was the only party interested in ensuring that workers received their just entitlements. I have been informed that the union has taken up the fight for these workers. The local organiser from Mount Isa, Hag Harrison, and the local organiser from Townsville, Bill Tew, have been pressuring and pursuing the company, or the voluntary administrators, and this will continue until employees receive their entitlements. A profitable sale of the mine may eventuate. However, workers should not have to risk part of their entitlements in the hope of receiving their full payment.

The government has an obligation to ensure that all workers receive what they are owed when an enterprise fails to pay the workers the money they are entitled to, especially when the company has gone into voluntary administration and, from voluntary administration, the receivers and managers have then used, as I understand it, a floating asset to continue the mine rather than distribute the money to employees who have been waiting for some time. On that basis, it becomes an absolute travesty of justice that workers are still waiting for their money some six months after the mine's closure when there was money available at the time.

The workers were apparently never asked if they wanted their entitlements reinvested in the mine, and it appears that the receivers are not obliged to ask for their permission. There seems to be a black hole in the legislation that provides for the receivers and managers to be able to use that entitlement to maintain the mine on a care basis until such time as the mine may be sold. The current legislation is clearly inadequate and offers minimal protection to workers in this predicament. I call on the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business to put in place legislative measures to ensure that these workers are paid in full. It is simply not good enough for the receivers to spend half a year seeking legal advice and hoping to sell the mine when workers and their families are still waiting for these entitlements.

Job entitlement protection legislation is desperately needed to ensure that workers are not forced to gamble part of their entitlement money in order to realise their total benefits. Workers should definitely not have to risk part of their entitlements to ensure that banks or creditors receive their share of the investment. Unless the sale of the Arimco mine yields a profit of—if my arithmetic is correct—about $15 million, workers will lose out again. The way it works is that the first $4.5 million is returned to the workers—which is the floating charge or as a consequence of the sale of the copper concentrate in assets—and the bank, Rothschilds, as I understand, is owed a further $9 million.

It is estimated that only after the banks receive their money will the rest of the workers' entitlements—the balance from the $4.5 million right up to the $6 million—be able to be accessed by the employees. This may or may not end up being the case; that is, the sale. But, regardless, it is not acceptable to take this sort of risk with other people's hard-earned money.

Workers deserve certainty. The government owes it to all working people to introduce job entitlement protection legislation to ensure that workers are paid what they are owed. I am aware of the discussion paper released recently by the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business on employee entitlements. I would seek that that legislation be drafted sooner rather than later, given that a considerable number of workers have already found themselves in this situation this year.

While I encourage any move to introduce measures protecting employee entitlements, the workers from the Selwyn Mine would not be protected from any future legislation. The government therefore needs to show some leadership and intervene to ensure that the workers are paid what they are owed.

The situation goes somewhat further, in that it does not confine itself to job protection entitlement legislation where a company may go into voluntary administration, receivers and managers are appointed and as a consequence, or due to the failure of the receivers and managers to resurrect the company, it may then go into liquidation. We have a unique situation where a floating charge has been used to continue the operation on a care and maintenance basis, without consultation—a discretionary decision, as I understand it, by the receivers and managers—which in effect takes away a certain $4.5 million that could have been used to pay out the employees' entitlements. As a consequence, they have had to wait a significant amount of time, and only if the mine is sold are they likely to receive a return.

An unfortunate situation could eventuate where the mine is sold, but only after some time; but what if the mine is not sold and the employees are left in the lurch for a far longer period? The receivers and managers under the voluntary administration scheme appear to have failed the workers by using that money for care and maintenance rather than to provide at least some relief to the employees. If all goes well, the mine may return an investment and be sold and the employees will receive their just entitlements. However, it is not a matter that should be left to the discretion of the voluntary administrator. Legislation should clearly provide an appropriate outcome, and those sorts of decisions should be made in consultation with the people who are likely to be affected—in this case the Selwyn Mine employees.

talk.start.para: —I think it is appropriate at this time to welcome Senator Ludwig and to congratulate him on his maiden speech in this place.

speech.para: It probably would have been more helpful to the workers of Australia if a plea such as the one made by the honourable senator opposite had been made 13 or 15 years ago in this place. He would know, from being a union organiser during the term of the Hawke and Keating governments—but particularly under Mr Keating's stewardship of the economy as Treasurer and then as Prime Minister—that those governments put the livelihoods of something like a million households across Australia in jeopardy. A million people were unemployed in 1992-93. A million households were without a breadwinner. Tens of thousands of businesses were sent to the wall by interest rates that peaked at over 30 per cent for businesses. It was a deliberate decision of those governments—those economic vandals.

I have not searched the records here, but I did not see that the honourable senator in his previous life as a union organiser pleaded for that government to protect the hundreds of thousands of workers who lost their daily bread, who lost their livelihood, who lost any chance of putting a roof over the heads of their children, and who could rely only on the unemployment benefits that were paid out by the Commonwealth government. Those people were in power for 13 years, and of the 13 years they ran budget deficits in 10 of them. The average deficit was $10 billion.

They drove government debt to historic high levels, and they drove interest rates up as a matter of choice and policy around the cabinet table, which drove tens of thousands of Australian businesses to the wall. And what did they do about workers' entitlements during those 13 years? Not a damn thing. And you have the gross hypocrisy as a member of the trade union movement to come into this place and lecture this government, which has done more about protecting workers' rights, more about protecting workers' entitlements than any Labor government in the past 13 years.
Senator Mark Bishop interjecting—

talk.start.para: —This opposition is an absolute and total disgrace, and for a former member of the Australian Workers Union to come in here and totally forget the absolute and abject—

speech.para: Senator Mark Bishop interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Bishop! Senator Campbell has the call and I expect him to be heard in silence.
—And you hear these union officials opposite squealing so loudly because they are so embarrassed by the inaction of the previous Labor government which destroyed the Australian economy.
—You are a disgraceful hypocrite!
—Senator Bishop, please withdraw your unparliamentary language.
—I withdraw.

—They are screaming and yelling, and breaching standing orders, because they are so embarrassed by the inaction of that government. The only action that was taken by that government that had an impact on workers' lives was to drive interest rates up past 30 per cent for businesses. If you read John Edwards's excellent biography of former Prime Minister Keating, you would see it says that Mr Keating knew, when he was Treasurer, that if you drive interest rates up past double digits then you put a lot of pressure on businesses. Where were the unions when tens of thousands of businesses—not a mine here and a mine there—were driven to the wall? Where were the unions when all of those workers—over one million of them in the end, one million breadwinners—had to come home and say, `Sorry, I've just lost my job'? Mr Keating—and I am sure Senator Bishop and Senator Ludwig would know this—made a policy decision to drive those businesses out of business and to drive those people home to their kids to say, `Sorry, no more income for the time being.' I get very angry when Labor senators come in here and say, `What about these workers?' What about those million workers during the recession, when Mr Keating and people like Senator Cook, the then employment minister, and Mr Beazley, the finance minister, sat around that cabinet table and made a deliberate decision to drive interest rates up above 30 per cent and drive people out of business? The hypocrisy is breathtaking.

speech.para: They have not changed their spots. They seek to be the government in this place again. They had the audacity to put their name up on the ballot paper at the last federal election. They want to be the government again. What is their policy? It is more government spending, higher taxes and, we presume, higher debt and higher interest rates again. The people of middle Australia will not forget going out to their letterboxes, collecting the envelope and dreading to see the bank's insignia on the front of the envelope because they knew what was inside it. It said, `Dear Mr and Mrs Australia, interest rates have gone up again,' because you had Mr Beazley and Mr Keating and Senator Cook and the others saying, `Let's keep borrowing and spending up. Let's spend future young Australians' money before they have a chance to vote about it and drive those interest rates up.' That is what these people opposite did.

Now they come in here and say, `What are you doing about it?' The record shows that this government has done more about workers' entitlements than what was done in 13 years of Labor government. They had the opportunity. I was in the Senate when they brought forward—
Senator Mark Bishop interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Bishop!

—They yell and squeal opposite because deep in their hearts they know that they were members of a party that, less than eight years ago, had before this chamber amendments to the Corporations Law to do exactly what Senator Ludwig is talking about, which is to put workers higher up the line of entitlements when a company goes into receivership or liquidation. What did the previous Labor government do? Nothing. They did not do what you said. They had 13 years to do it. They had 13 years to put in place workers' entitlements legislation. Go and speak to your mate Greg Combet.

speech.para: I met Greg Combet on the front lawn outside this place. I said, `Greg, can you tell us why the Labor Party didn't do this?' He said, `I don't know.' He was very angry about it. I am sure that if Senator Ludwig and Senator Bishop go and talk to Mr Combet in a quiet room where they promise not to say what each other says, Greg Combet will tell you that the Labor Party had the opportunity to do it. A report was done, and what did they do about it? Nothing. No wonder Mr Combet thought the previous government was hopeless. Let us hope that you can face up to the total lack of action.

They have not changed their spots. Here they are talking about mining companies. What did they do in 1993 on native title legislation? They brought in a piece of legislation that virtually obliterated exploration in Australia. It obliterated anything but brown fields exploration. It destroyed it. Tomorrow they will have a chance to vote on a disallowance motion which will either place mining and exploration in the Northern Territory at risk or allow it to go ahead. We saw how Senator Bishop from Western Australia voted on the native title legislation. He sold down his own state. We have not had a chance to see how Senator Ludwig will vote on native title issues. That is where we will see how serious they are about supporting the rights of workers in Australia to continue the efforts of a great Australian industry: mining and exploration.

Do you want to blanket Australia with a legislative regime that makes it virtually impossible to get an exploration project going, or do you want to allow the states and territories to get on with implementing regimes that will allow the great mining provinces of Queensland and Western Australia to go on being explored and to go on creating wealth for all Australians, particularly for those families who leave the capital cities and go to the regional areas, put up with tough condi tions and work in those great mining provinces to explore and create future wealth creation opportunities? Or do you want to ensure that Mr Keating's native title law smothers Queensland and Western Australia? We will see how these gentlemen opposite vote tomorrow on native title issues. We will watch them very closely and we will see whether the words we heard tonight were not abject and total hypocrisy.
